title: Two Sum
description: Given an array of integers 'nums' and an integer 'target', return the indices of the two numbers such that they add up to 'target'. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.
input_format: An array of integers nums and an integer target.
output_format: An array of two integers representing the indices of the nums array.
constraints: Assume that there is exactly one solution.

examples.explanation: nums[0] + nums[1] == 2 + 7 == 9, so we return the indices [0, 1].
nums[1] + nums[2] == 2 + 4 == 6, so we return the indices [1, 2].

hints: Use a hash table to track the numbers you have seen.
The target can be found by checking if the complement (target - current number) exists in the hash table.

title: Palindrome Linked List
description: Given a singly linked list, determine if it is a palindrome. A palindrome is a sequence that reads the same backward as forward. For example, the linked list 1 -> 2 -> 2 -> 1 is a palindrome, while 1 -> 2 -> 3 is not.
input_format: The first line contains an integer n, which is the number of nodes in the linked list. The second line contains n integers, which are the values of the nodes in the linked list.
output_format: Return true if the linked list is a palindrome, otherwise return false.

examples.explanation: The linked list is 1 -> 2 -> 2 -> 1, which is a palindrome.
The linked list is 1 -> 2 -> 3, which is not a palindrome.

hints: Consider using a slow and fast pointer to find the middle of the linked list.
Reverse the second half of the linked list and compare it with the first half.
